articles.title: How Jane Goodall changed the way we see animals – and the world
articles.summary: Jane Goodall, who chronicled the social lives of chimps, has died, but she leaves a lasting legacy on how we view the natural world
articles.content:
Jane Goodall, who chronicled the social lives of chimps, has died, but she leaves a lasting legacy on how we view the natural world

Jane Goodall transformed our understanding of chimps Europa Press Reportajes/Europa Press/Avalon

Jane Goodall, who has died aged 91, changed the world through the way she saw animals, particularly chimps.

In 1960, when she was 26, she observed a chimp she had named David Greybeard fishing for termites with a twig he had stripped of leaves. “At that time,” she later said, “it was thought that humans, and only humans, used and made tools. I had been told from school onwards that the best definition of a human being was man the tool-maker – yet I had just watched a chimp tool-maker in action.”

Advertisement

She reported her finding to her mentor, the palaeoanthropologist Louis Leakey, who sent a famous telegram in reply: “Now we must redefine ‘tool’, redefine ‘man’, or accept chimpanzees as humans.”

In the end, we chose the middle option and looked for some other thing that we could do that other animals couldn’t. But Goodall’s work was vital to undermining the view of human exceptionalism and superiority that had prevailed not just among scientists but in society as a whole.

Goodall in the television special Miss Goodall and the Wild Chimpanzees, filmed in Tanzania and originally broadcast on CBS in December 1965 CBS via Getty Images

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

Her work took aim at the assumption of the French philosopher René Descartes that had propped up the exploitation of animals and the destruction of the environment for 400 years. Descartes said animals have no soul and can be considered machines for us to use as we will. Goodall showed that chimps had the intelligence and foresight to design and build tools, but she also ascribed them emotions and personalities. Some were calm, like David Greybeard, others timid, curious or feisty.

In this, her worked echoed that of another world-changing scientist with similarly brilliant observational powers. In his book The Expressions of the Emotions in Man and Animals, Charles Darwin attempted to explain the evolution of facial expressions, ascribing them to emotional states: jealousy, rage, love and so on. But he did so in animals as well as humans, and the establishment rejected it.

The book was poorly regarded at the time and neglected for more than 100 years. Goodall’s work in the 1960s was also initially dismissed and even scorned. It didn’t help that she was a young woman with no degree. Both Darwin and Goodall were driven by unquenchable curiosity and a power of patient, intense observation – and these qualities underlie their success. (When New Scientist once asked her what young scientists need, she replied, “Patience, in huge oodles and bucketfuls.”) We now understand that both Darwin and Goodall were right: many animals have feelings, emotions and inner lives.

Goodall with the chimp she named David Greybeard in 1965 Granger/Shutterstock

Goodall was chosen by Leakey to study chimpanzees at Gombe in what is now Tanzania. Leakey was interested in understanding human evolution and deducing the behaviour of the common ancestor of chimps and humans, and he decided that studying wild chimpanzees, which no one had ever done, would be a good way to go about it. He wanted someone who was unbiased by established scientific thinking, and he believed a woman would make a more patient, empathetic field biologist. It is unlikely that a trained biologist would have made the breakthroughs that Goodall did.

At first, her observations of chimps were distant glimpses, through binoculars. But gradually she won their acceptance. The first to trust her was the one she called David Greybeard, a male with white hairs on his chin. (She would later, taking a PhD at Cambridge, be reprimanded for giving the animals names and not numbers, but to her it was natural to name them all.) She saw David Greybeard stripping leaves from a twig and then using it to fish termites from a termite mound, and reported her findings to Leakey. “David Greybeard and his tool using was the moment that changed everything,” she later said.

She was also the first scientist to make descriptions of chimp courtship and mating rituals, of their reproductive cycles, and of how mothers introduce their babies to the troop – experienced mothers, Goodall found, calmly allowed the others of the troop to see the baby, whereas first-time mothers hid the baby, provoking hooting and mayhem in the troop.

Goodall at UNESCO headquarters in Paris, France, in February 2018 AGENCE 18/SIPA/Shutterstock

In the 1970s, the focus of her life began to change, moving from observing chimps to championing them. So began her second phase of changing the world. She established the Jane Goodall Institute in 1977, which became a vast non-profit conservation organisation, with offices in 25 countries. In 1986 she organised a conference for field biologists working on chimps at sites across Africa, and it drove home the threat facing the animals and the forests they rely on. She also learned about the problems facing people who live near the chimps’ habitats.

In 1991 she started Roots & Shoots, an organisation aimed at teaching young people about conservation. It is active in over 75 countries. Constantly touring and speaking on conservation, she gave around 300 public appearances a year. In 2024, she visited each of the offices of the Jane Goodall Institute to speak to the media about conservation work and the rights of animals.

Goodall died in California, in the middle of a speaking tour. She wrote 32 books, including 15 for children. In her final one, The Book of Hope, she wrote: “I realised that if we couldn’t help people find a way of making a living without destroying the environment, there was no way we could try to save the chimpanzees.”

Goodall spoke of the influence of another of the 20th century’s most important figures, the ecologist and conservationist Rachel Carson. At the University of Cambridge in the 1960s, she said, “I read Rachel Carson’s Silent Spring and was inspired by her courage in battling with pharmaceutical companies, the government and scientists about the danger to the environment of DDT.”

Carson knew there was a long fight ahead but never gave up and will continue to inspire, she said. The same is true of Jane Goodall.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Jane Goodall's transformative impact on how humans understand and relate to animals and the natural world, emphasizing her pioneering scientific discoveries about chimpanzees, her challenge to long-held beliefs about human exceptionalism, and her extensive conservation efforts through the Jane Goodall Institute and Roots & Shoots. This legacy has broad significance for environmental conservation and animal welfare worldwide.
articles.personality_title: Jane Goodall’s lasting impact on how we understand animals and nature
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Jane Goodall was a scientist who studied chimpanzees in the wild starting in 1960. Before her work, many people believed that only humans used tools and had emotions. 

**What happened** – When Jane was 26, she watched a chimpanzee named David Greybeard use a stick to catch termites. This was the first time a chimpanzee was seen making and using tools, which challenged old ideas about what makes humans special. She spent many years observing chimpanzees closely, learning about their behaviors, emotions, and social lives. Later, she founded the Jane Goodall Institute and Roots & Shoots, organizations that help protect chimpanzees and teach young people about caring for the environment.

**Impact** – Jane Goodall’s discoveries showed that animals like chimpanzees are smart and have feelings. This changed how scientists and many people think about animals and nature. Her work helped protect chimpanzees and their forests, and inspired millions to care more about wildlife and the environment. She also proved that patient observation and kindness can lead to important scientific discoveries.

**What's next step** – The Jane Goodall Institute continues to work in over 25 countries, protecting animals and their habitats. Roots & Shoots is active in more than 75 countries, teaching young people to take care of the planet. Jane’s work encourages future scientists and conservationists to keep learning from animals and to find ways to live in harmony with nature.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Jane Goodall changed how we see animals by showing their intelligence and emotions, inspiring efforts to protect wildlife and the environment worldwide.

articles.title: Scientists just recreated a wildfire that made its own weather
articles.summary: In 2020, California’s Creek Fire became so intense that it generated its own thunderstorm, a phenomenon called a pyrocumulonimbus cloud. For years, scientists struggled to replicate these explosive fire-born storms in climate models, leaving major gaps in understanding their global effects. Now, a new study has finally simulated them successfully, reproducing the Creek Fire’s storm and others like it.
articles.content:
On September 5, 2020, California's Creek Fire grew so severe that it began producing it's own weather system. The fire's extreme heat produced an explosive thunderhead that spewed lightning strikes and further fanned the roaring flames, making containment elusive and endangering the lives of firefighters on the ground. These wildfire-born storms have become a growing part of fire seasons across the West, with lasting impacts on air quality, weather, and climate. Until now, scientists have struggled to replicate them in Earth system models, hindering our ability to predict their occurrence and understand their impacts on the global climate. Now, a new study provides a breakthrough by developing a novel wildfire-Earth system modeling framework.

The research, published September 25th in Geophysical Research Letters, represents the first successful simulation of these wildfire-induced storms, known as pyrocumulonimbus clouds, within an Earth system model. Led by DRI scientist Ziming Ke, the study successfully reproduced the observed timing, height, and strength of the Creek Fire's thunderhead - one of the largest known pyrocumulonimbus clouds seen in the U.S., according to NASA. The model also replicated multiple thunderstorms produced by the 2021 Dixie Fire, which occurred under very different conditions. Accounting for the way that cloud development is aided by moisture lofted into the higher reaches of the atmosphere by terrain and winds is key to their findings.

"This work is a first-of-its-kind breakthrough in Earth system modeling," Ke said. "It not only demonstrates how extreme wildfire events can be studied within Earth system models, but also establishes DRI's growing capability in Earth system model development -- a core strength that positions the institute to lead future advances in wildfire-climate science."

When a pyrocumulonimbus cloud forms, it injects smoke and moisture into the upper atmosphere at magnitudes comparable to those of small volcanic eruptions, impacting the way Earth's atmosphere receives and reflects sunlight. These fire aerosols can persist for months or longer, altering stratospheric composition. When transported to polar regions, they affect Antarctic ozone dynamics, modify clouds and albedo, and accelerate ice and snow melt, reshaping polar climate feedbacks. Scientists estimate that tens to hundreds of these storms occur globally each year, and that the trend of increasingly severe wildfires will only grow their numbers. Until now, failing to incorporate these storms into Earth system models has hindered our ability to understand this natural disturbance's impact on global climate.

The research team also included scientists from Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, U.C. Irvine, and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory. Their breakthrough leveraged the Department of Energy's (DOE) Energy Exascale Earth System Model (E3SM) to successfully capture the complex interplay between wildfires and the atmosphere.

"Our team developed a novel wildfire-Earth system modeling framework that integrates high-resolution wildfire emissions, a one-dimensional plume-rise model, and fire-induced water vapor transport into DOE's cutting-edge Earth system model," Ke said. "This breakthrough advances high-resolution modeling of extreme hazards to improve national resilience and preparedness, and provides the framework for future exploration of these storms at regional and global scales within Earth system models."
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in successfully simulating wildfire-induced storms (pyrocumulonimbus clouds) within Earth system models for the first time. This advancement addresses a major gap in understanding the global climate impacts of extreme wildfires, which are increasing in frequency and severity. The research has broad implications for climate science, atmospheric modeling, and improving preparedness and resilience against wildfire hazards, benefiting society at large.
articles.personality_title: Scientists recreate wildfire storms to better predict climate impacts
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2020, California’s Creek Fire became so intense that it created its own thunderstorm, called a pyrocumulonimbus cloud. These fire-made storms are powerful and hard to predict, and until now, scientists could not simulate them in climate models.

**What happened** – A new study led by scientist Ziming Ke has successfully recreated these wildfire storms using a special Earth system model. The research reproduced the Creek Fire’s thunderstorm from 2020 and similar storms from the 2021 Dixie Fire. The team used advanced techniques to show how smoke, heat, and moisture from fires interact with the atmosphere to form these clouds.

**Impact** – This is the first time wildfire-created storms have been accurately simulated in climate models. It helps scientists understand how these storms affect weather and climate, including how smoke reaches high into the atmosphere and changes sunlight, air quality, and even polar ice melting. This breakthrough fills a major gap in predicting the effects of growing wildfire seasons worldwide.

**What's next step** – Researchers will use this new model to study wildfire storms on larger regional and global scales. This will improve climate predictions and help prepare for future wildfire hazards by showing how fires and weather influence each other.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have for the first time recreated wildfire-born thunderstorms in climate models, improving our understanding of their role in Earth’s weather and climate systems.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques recréent les orages créés par les incendies pour mieux prévoir le climat
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2020, l’incendie de Creek en Californie est devenu si intense qu’il a créé son propre orage, appelé un nuage pyrocumulonimbus. Ces orages produits par le feu sont puissants et difficiles à prévoir, et jusqu’à présent, les scientifiques ne pouvaient pas les simuler dans les modèles climatiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une nouvelle étude dirigée par le scientifique Ziming Ke a réussi à recréer ces orages d’incendie en utilisant un modèle spécial du système terrestre. La recherche a reproduit l’orage de l’incendie de Creek en 2020 ainsi que des orages similaires de l’incendie Dixie en 2021. L’équipe a utilisé des techniques avancées pour montrer comment la fumée, la chaleur et l’humidité des incendies interagissent avec l’atmosphère pour former ces nuages.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des orages créés par des incendies sont simulés avec précision dans des modèles climatiques. Cela aide les scientifiques à comprendre comment ces orages affectent la météo et le climat, notamment comment la fumée monte haut dans l’atmosphère et modifie la lumière du soleil, la qualité de l’air et même la fonte des glaces polaires. Cette avancée comble une grande lacune dans la prévision des effets des saisons d’incendies croissantes dans le monde.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs utiliseront ce nouveau modèle pour étudier ces orages d’incendie à plus grande échelle régionale et mondiale. Cela améliorera les prévisions climatiques et aidera à mieux se préparer aux risques futurs liés aux incendies en montrant comment les incendies et la météo s’influencent mutuellement.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont recréé pour la première fois des orages nés des incendies dans des modèles climatiques, améliorant la compréhension de leur rôle dans les systèmes météorologiques et climatiques de la Terre.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos recrean tormentas creadas por incendios para mejorar predicciones climáticas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2020, el incendio Creek en California se volvió tan intenso que creó su propia tormenta, llamada nube pirocumulonimbus. Estas tormentas formadas por el fuego son poderosas y difíciles de predecir, y hasta ahora los científicos no podían simularlas en modelos climáticos.

**Qué pasó** – Un nuevo estudio liderado por el científico Ziming Ke logró recrear estas tormentas de incendios usando un modelo especial del sistema terrestre. La investigación reprodujo la tormenta del incendio Creek de 2020 y otras similares del incendio Dixie en 2021. El equipo utilizó técnicas avanzadas para mostrar cómo el humo, el calor y la humedad de los incendios interactúan con la atmósfera para formar estas nubes.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que se simulan con precisión estas tormentas creadas por incendios en modelos climáticos. Esto ayuda a los científicos a entender cómo estas tormentas afectan el clima y el tiempo, incluyendo cómo el humo llega alto en la atmósfera y cambia la luz solar, la calidad del aire e incluso el derretimiento del hielo polar. Este avance llena un gran vacío en la predicción de los efectos de temporadas de incendios cada vez más fuertes en todo el mundo.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores usarán este nuevo modelo para estudiar estas tormentas de incendios a escalas regionales y globales más grandes. Esto mejorará las predicciones climáticas y ayudará a prepararse mejor para futuros peligros de incendios mostrando cómo los incendios y el clima se afectan mutuamente.

**Resumen en una frase** – Por primera vez, científicos han recreado tormentas nacidas de incendios en modelos climáticos, mejorando la comprensión de su papel en los sistemas climáticos y meteorológicos de la Tierra.

articles.title: Why green bus stops are blooming around the world
articles.summary:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM Most bus stops serve a simple function: keep commuters dry and out of the sun. But in cities across the globe, a quiet revolution is taking shape overhead. Green bus shelters, compact rooftops planted with succulents, wildflowers, and native grasses, are turning everyday infrastructure into tiny urban oases. Once […]
The post Why green bus stops are blooming around the world first appeared on The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News.
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

Most bus stops serve a simple function: keep commuters dry and out of the sun. But in cities across the globe, a quiet revolution is taking shape overhead. Green bus shelters, compact rooftops planted with succulents, wildflowers, and native grasses, are turning everyday infrastructure into tiny urban oases.

Once a quirky feature in the Netherlands, these living roofs have been popping up across Europe, Asia, and North America. Boston recently installed 30 of them, and two towns in Maryland (Bladensburg and Edmonston) will soon follow. Proposals are underway in Arlington, Virginia, and New York. These little gardens offer more than a charming view: they help cool cities, support local wildlife, and nudge communities toward greener thinking.

A small fix with big potential

Green roofs have long been a fixture on city buildings, but bus shelters bring nature down to eye level. While a single roof garden might seem insignificant, their collective power adds up. Boston estimates that if every one of its 8,000 bus stops had a green roof, the total green space would equal 17 acres; that’s about the size of 13 football fields.

These installations serve a practical purpose, too. “It’s the accumulation of those small, small things you will be doing that will have an impact in the long run,” says Jean-Luc Martel, professor at École de Technologie Supérieure in Montreal.

In fact, living roofs have been shown to reduce surrounding air temperatures by up to 20 degrees Fahrenheit, a significant benefit in cities battling the urban heat island effect.

What goes into a green bus shelter?

Building a green bus stop requires careful planning. The structure must be strong enough to handle the weight of soil, water, and plants. From there, the setup typically includes:

A root barrier to stop downward plant growth

to stop downward plant growth A drainage system that stores rainwater and releases it gradually

that stores rainwater and releases it gradually Special lightweight soil that retains water but won’t overburden the roof

that retains water but won’t overburden the roof A selection of vegetation, ideally native plants that support biodiversity

Sedums, hardy little succulents, are a favorite choice. “You can basically toss them into really extreme environments and somehow they’ve found a way to survive and thrive,” says Larry Davis of Green Mechanics, an ecological design firm in Maryland.

A boost for pollinators and biodiversity

For Utrecht, in the Netherlands, green bus shelters are part of a wider mission to save bees. Strategically placed throughout the city, these living roofs form “bee lines” that help sustain pollinators with consistent food sources. Their efforts may be paying off: the national bee census, which enlists citizens to count bees in their gardens, has shown signs of stabilization.

In Boston, the new green shelters have drawn more than just curious glances. “We’ve seen butterflies, bees, birds, even squirrels,” says Zoe Davis, the city’s senior climate resilience project manager.

Shifting how we see our cities

While some U.S. installations are still in the demonstration phase like those in San Francisco, Philadelphia, and East Lansing, Michigan, their impact goes beyond data. Since they’re at street level, green bus shelters are more visible than green roofs atop tall buildings. They encourage commuters to imagine new possibilities for public space.

In the end, these bus stops may be small, but their message is big: nature belongs everywhere, even on your daily commute.
articles.source: The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News

articles.personality_title_es: Paradas de autobús verdes llevan la naturaleza a las ciudades
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La mayoría de las paradas de autobús solo protegen a las personas de la lluvia y el sol. Pero en ciudades de todo el mundo, están agregando techos verdes con plantas, convirtiendo estos refugios en pequeños jardines.

**Qué pasó** – Ciudades en Europa, Asia y América del Norte están construyendo paradas de autobús verdes con plantas como suculentas y flores silvestres en sus techos. Boston ha instalado 30, y pueblos en Maryland planean agregar más. Estos techos vivos ayudan a enfriar el aire, apoyan a animales como abejas y mariposas, y animan a las personas a pensar más en la naturaleza.

**Impacto** – Aunque pequeños, estos techos verdes suman mucho. Si las 8,000 paradas de autobús en Boston tuvieran plantas, sería igual a 17 acres de espacio verde. Las plantas pueden bajar la temperatura cercana hasta 20 grados Fahrenheit, ayudando a combatir el calor de la ciudad. También crean alimento y hogar para polinizadores, protegiendo estos insectos importantes.

**Próximo paso** – Más ciudades, como Arlington y Nueva York, planean agregar paradas de autobús verdes. A medida que esta idea crece, podría cambiar cómo las personas ven los espacios públicos e inspirar más proyectos amigables con la naturaleza en las ciudades.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las paradas de autobús verdes convierten lugares comunes en pequeños jardines que enfrían el aire y ayudan a la vida silvestre, mostrando cómo cambios simples pueden mejorar la vida urbana.

articles.title: An absurdist theater artist prepares New Yorkers for climate disasters
articles.content:
Edgemere Farm was born out of a climate catastrophe and community resilience. In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, volunteers transformed an abandoned, flood-damaged, city-owned plot into a lush organic garden.

One day in mid-September, the half-acre site in Far Rockaway, New York, underwent another makeover: For an hour, it became a chai shop. Two hundred people gathered to watch a performance of Flood Sensor Aunty, an hour-long play written by local urban planner and theater artist Sabina Sethi Unni. She stars as an humanized flood sensor — a tool that detects high water levels and delivers that data to a publicly-accessible map.

Sethi Unni’s anthropomorphized device clashes with her chai-shop coworkers and dreams of becoming a movie star. A pair of lovelorn city health inspectors, an attention-seeking city council member, and a rain god running a cult out of a cramped one-bedroom apartment round out the cast.

Many people associate urban flooding with cities like New Orleans and Miami. But it’s becoming more frequent further north, too. Thirty-four of the 43 people killed when Hurricane Sandy pummeled New York City in 2012 drowned in storm-surge flooding, many of them in low-lying neighborhoods. The rain that followed Hurricane Ida’s march up the coast in 2021 killed 13 people, 11 of them in basement apartments. Even a heavy downpour like the one New York experienced in July can inundate homes and threaten lives.

Flood Sensor Aunty strives to educate people about the threat by combining absurdist comedy with practical advice for surviving disasters yet to come. It celebrates the power of the community to overcome crises, while providing audiences with useful, tangible tools like free flood alarms and headlamps provided in collaboration with the city’s Office of Emergency Management and local nonprofits. The play explains how to access 311 and make a disaster plan — through a synth-heavy, brightly-costumed, Chappell-Roan-referencing extravaganza performed in parks, warehouses, and, on at least one occasion, a boat.

Sethi Unni talked about her work at Climate Week in September and recently performed her play in Boston. She hopes to take on other dramatic topics, like community board meetings — and wants to see more artists tackling the climate crisis with humor and hope.

Grist caught up with Sethi Unni to discuss public art as disaster preparedness infrastructure, Facebook pages and gossipy families as artistic inspiration, and just what a flood sensor is, anyway.

This conversation has been edited for length and clarity.

Q: How did you start making climate change theater?





A: Hurricane Ida was a real revelation in terms of the gaps we have in reaching South Asian and Indo-Caribbean communities. People live in basement apartments, which are largely illegal, so people are afraid to reach out to the city. They can’t access tenant protections. They’re just trapped in this net.

People talk about flooding as something that happens when you’re on the coast. But a lot of the neighborhoods most impacted by Ida were inland neighborhoods in Queens with high groundwater tables. In the communities we perform in, like South Queens, flooding is so real, and basement-apartment deaths are real. And the city historically, even though they’re really trying to take all these creative approaches, hasn’t done a great job reaching communities that don’t speak English, communities of color, communities that don’t place faith and trust in the government.

I was in planning school during Hurricane Ida. A lot of my classes were all about how we can floodproof the city. The responses were very top-down — like, “We have to build a sea wall.” Sometimes that’s the right call, but sometimes more soft care infrastructure is what we need. What if more people knew what flooding is? What if we change our politics around basement apartments? I was looking at this as a way to reach communities where they’re at, with trusted messengers [and] cultural references.

In the American consciousness, disasters, specifically flooding and hurricanes, are seen as apolitical. But obviously, where people live in cities is caused by redlining and segregation. In New York, public housing is often in low-lying areas. And a lot of Asian American and Pacific Islander immigrants live in these basement apartments.

Q: What inspired this play — and what, exactly, is a flood sensor?





A: I’m part of this Facebook page called Community Flood Watch. It’s mostly one guy from Howard Beach posting NOAA reports about flooding in Howard Beach. I’m obsessed with floods. Normally, people report flooding through 311 calls. But you have to know what 311 is, you more or less have to speak English, and you have to have the time to call. So [flood sensors] are a good alternative. They produce an alternate form of data that can, hopefully, be used for advocacy.

A flood sensor is super cute. It’s a device that’s put on high surfaces that calculates the distance between whatever height it’s placed at and the ground. When it rains, the distance between it and the ground changes because of the water level. But flood sensors also kind of look like surveillance cameras. So we’re trying to get the word out about this kind of wonky LIDAR technology.

I also think it’s a really good, physical way to talk about flooding, because flooding is very ephemeral, and a flood sensor is very much a thing that exists in the here and now.

Q: It’s still there between the floods.





A: Exactly. It exists when it rains, it exists when it’s sunny. Inland flooding isn’t something that you talk about a lot unless you’re used to your block flooding. But it’s a very severe issue.

Q: So, what role can art play in educating people about these ephemeral but also dangerous things?





A: I think it’s a healthy part of the ecosystem. I think people respond to art — people respond to humor and entertainment and coolness and joy in their neighborhoods. It’s a way of captivating folks. People need information repeated in different ways, whether that’s through song and dance or jazz hands and sock puppets. Sometimes a one-page pamphlet translated into two languages isn’t the best way for people to receive information, but a song about go-bags played on the synth is.

At every performance of Flood Sensor Aunty, audience members go home with free chai, headlamps, and flood alarms. Courtesy of New York City Department of Emergency Management

Q: I was struck by how much of the play is about hyperlocal politics. We see people negotiating bureaucracy in order to make a life, build community, survive — the chai shop owners fight a mid-level bureaucrat who very much wants them shut down. So, I now ask: As we navigate the climate crisis, should we have sympathy for bureaucrats?

A: We should and shouldn’t. The show is partially a suggestion to bureaucrats that we can use creative strategies in informing communities about their risk. It doesn’t just have to be a top down thing, or a boring community-board visit. [Flood Sensor Aunty] is making a little fun of bureaucrats who are sticklers about permits, and can cause a lot of harm by acting like urban-planning cops.

But it is also a love letter to our bureaucrats who are trying to make change and push back against this big, uncaring system. We actually have a bureaucrat, Jill Cornell, whom I reached out to for technical assistance. Jill does community engagement with the City Office of Emergency Management. And now she has a monologue in the show, and she’s singing and dancing, and she’s maybe a better dancer than all of us.

Q: At one point, your character in Flood Sensor Aunty says “gossip saves lives.” Is that true?

A: Gossip totally saves lives. Aunty gossip saves lives. In a real sense, folks who are doing the domestic work in households are doing a lot of disaster work. This awesome civil engineer named Sangamithra Iyer, who gave a talkback at one of our performances last spring, spoke about how care work is infrastructure, and the work of women in households is climate infrastructure. Gossip can mean knowing what neighbors I’m supposed to be checking on — this neighbor always takes a walk at this time of day, and I haven’t seen them; these neighbors are elderly, I should probably call them. That kind of gossipy, busybody work is how we save lives.

I talk about my real neighbors in the show. We share mint from our gardens, feed the same stray cats, check in on each other after storms.

Q: Trying to get attention in a busy public park is difficult. How do you get your message across despite all the noise and distraction that being in public in a big city implies?

A: It’s usually just being the boldest and brightest thing. When we were creating our set, we were like, “What color contrasts best against green and blue?” But we want to let the place shine through — like, if we’re in Edgemere, we’re in Edgemere. The beautiful tomato stalks are part of the set, too.

There’s this genre within public art called “useful art.” Even if you don’t really listen to what we’re saying, we’re giving you a go-bag, we’re giving you a flood alarm, we’re giving you a headlamp, we’re giving you all these resources to keep yourself safe. A lot of people think plays are really good opportunities to change hearts and minds, but sometimes people just need to know what’s going on. Maybe they should think about the racial politics of social risk, but maybe they also just need a flood alarm for their basement, too.

There’s a mainstream climate policy belief that we protect ourselves against flooding through Army Corps of Engineers projects, like a sea wall. But what if, also, the things that keep us safe are knowing our neighbors, loving our aunties, checking in on elderly people in our communities? These soft forms of infrastructure also deserve funding and attention, and should be seen as real forms of infrastructure, too.

articles.personality_title: New York artist uses theater to teach about flood safety and community care
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – After Hurricane Sandy in 2012 caused deadly flooding in New York City, many neighborhoods were left vulnerable to future storms. Flooding is a growing problem not just on the coast but also inland, especially in low-lying areas where many people live in basement apartments.

**What happened** – Sabina Sethi Unni, a theater artist and urban planner, created a play called Flood Sensor Aunty to help New Yorkers understand flood risks and prepare for disasters. The play was performed at Edgemere Farm in Far Rockaway, a community garden started after Sandy. It uses humor and characters like a human flood sensor and city workers to explain how flooding works and how to stay safe. The show also gives out free flood alarms, headlamps, and emergency supplies.

**Impact** – This project is unique because it reaches communities often left out of official safety messages, such as immigrants living in basement apartments who may not speak English well or trust the government. By mixing comedy, local stories, and practical advice, the play helps people learn important safety tips in a way that feels friendly and relatable. It also shows how neighbors caring for each other is a key part of staying safe during floods.

**What's next step** – Sabina Sethi Unni plans to bring the play to more places, including Boston, and wants to create other shows about community life and climate challenges. She hopes more artists will use humor and creativity to talk about climate change and disaster preparedness.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A New York artist is using theater and community connections to teach people how to prepare for floods and support each other during disasters.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une artiste new-yorkaise utilise le théâtre pour sensibiliser aux risques d’inondation et à l’entraide communautaire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Après l’ouragan Sandy en 2012, qui a provoqué des inondations meurtrières à New York, de nombreux quartiers sont restés vulnérables aux futures tempêtes. Les inondations deviennent un problème croissant non seulement sur la côte mais aussi à l’intérieur des terres, notamment dans les zones basses où beaucoup vivent dans des appartements en sous-sol.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Sabina Sethi Unni, artiste de théâtre et urbaniste, a créé une pièce appelée Flood Sensor Aunty pour aider les New-Yorkais à comprendre les risques d’inondation et à se préparer aux catastrophes. La pièce a été jouée à Edgemere Farm à Far Rockaway, un jardin communautaire créé après Sandy. Elle utilise l’humour et des personnages comme un capteur d’inondation humain et des travailleurs municipaux pour expliquer le fonctionnement des inondations et comment rester en sécurité. Le spectacle distribue aussi gratuitement des alarmes anti-inondation, des lampes frontales et du matériel d’urgence.

**Impact** – Ce projet est unique car il atteint des communautés souvent exclues des messages officiels de sécurité, comme les immigrants vivant dans des sous-sols qui ne parlent pas bien anglais ou ne font pas confiance au gouvernement. En combinant comédie, histoires locales et conseils pratiques, la pièce aide les gens à apprendre des gestes de sécurité importants de manière conviviale et accessible. Elle montre aussi que prendre soin de ses voisins est essentiel pour rester en sécurité lors des inondations.

**Prochaine étape** – Sabina Sethi Unni prévoit de présenter la pièce dans d’autres villes, comme Boston, et souhaite créer d’autres spectacles sur la vie communautaire et les défis climatiques. Elle espère que davantage d’artistes utiliseront l’humour et la créativité pour parler du changement climatique et de la préparation aux catastrophes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une artiste new-yorkaise utilise le théâtre et les liens communautaires pour apprendre aux habitants à se préparer aux inondations et à s’entraider en cas de catastrophe.
articles.personality_title_es: Artista de Nueva York usa teatro para enseñar sobre seguridad ante inundaciones y cuidado comunitario
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Después del huracán Sandy en 2012, que causó inundaciones mortales en la ciudad de Nueva York, muchos barrios quedaron vulnerables a futuras tormentas. Las inundaciones son un problema creciente no solo en la costa, sino también en zonas interiores bajas donde muchas personas viven en apartamentos en sótanos.

**Qué pasó** – Sabina Sethi Unni, artista de teatro y urbanista, creó una obra llamada Flood Sensor Aunty para ayudar a los neoyorquinos a entender los riesgos de inundación y cómo prepararse para desastres. La obra se presentó en Edgemere Farm en Far Rockaway, un jardín comunitario creado tras Sandy. Usa humor y personajes como un sensor de inundación humano y trabajadores municipales para explicar cómo funcionan las inundaciones y cómo mantenerse seguros. También regala alarmas contra inundaciones, linternas frontales y suministros de emergencia.

**Impacto** – Este proyecto es especial porque llega a comunidades que a menudo quedan fuera de los mensajes oficiales de seguridad, como inmigrantes que viven en sótanos y que quizá no hablan bien inglés o no confían en el gobierno. Al mezclar comedia, historias locales y consejos prácticos, la obra ayuda a las personas a aprender importantes medidas de seguridad de forma amigable y cercana. También muestra que cuidar a los vecinos es clave para mantenerse seguro durante las inundaciones.

**Próximo paso** – Sabina Sethi Unni planea llevar la obra a más lugares, incluido Boston, y quiere crear otros espectáculos sobre la vida comunitaria y los desafíos climáticos. Espera que más artistas usen el humor y la creatividad para hablar sobre el cambio climático y la preparación para desastres.

**Frase clave** – Una artista de Nueva York usa el teatro y la conexión comunitaria para enseñar a las personas a prepararse para las inundaciones y apoyarse mutuamente en desastres.
